## Sensor-Aufnahmen Verwalten

In diesem Menü können Sie Langzeitaufnahmen, die der SMART-Sensor erstellt hat, zum HMG 4000 übertragen oder diese aus dem Speicher des SMART-Sensors löschen. Mit "**Aktualisieren**" wird geprüft, ob neue Aufnahmen vorhanden sind. Nach Auswahl einer Aufnahme und der Option "**Übertragen**" erhalten Sie eine Ansicht, in der Sie festlegen können, ob die ausgewählte Aufnahme unter der zuvor angezeigten Kombination aus Namen und Nummer im HMG 4000 abgelegt werden soll oder eine neue Verknüpfung vergeben werden soll. 

## Sensoreinstellungen

IO_ADC_23,* IO_PWD_00 ... IO_PWD_05, IO_DO_00 ... IO_DO_15 or IO_PVG_00 ... IO_PVG_07.

## Hs Pwm Output:

The I/O driver's diagnostic module continuously compares the desired output duty cycle and frequency with the feedback measurements, thus allowing to reliably detect failures within the PWM output stages. This measure is active for every PWM high side output that is initialized as safety-critical and will trigger an error callback in case of dangerous failures. Due to their superior diagnostic capabilities, the system integrator is advised to use the PWM output mode rather than the digital output mode for safety-critical applications, even if the corresponding actuators are only operated statically. This can be achieved by implementing a pseude-digital mode, that only changes between minimum and maximum output duty cycles.

Das HMG 4000 ist ein mobiles Handmessgerät mit einem vollgrafikfähigen Farbdisplay zur Messwertanzeige bzw. Messwertaufzeichnung. In Verbindung mit dem HMG 4000 können die aktuellen Messwerte des HYDACLAB sowie die gespeicherten Messkurven auf dem Display des HMG 4000 angezeigt werden. Diese Aufnahmen können mit dem HMG 4000 auch bearbeitet werden. Ferner kann über das HMG 4000 ein Reset des HYDACLAB vorgenommen werden. 

(genaue Beschreibung siehe Bedienungsanleitung HMG 4000). Bestell-Nr.: 925281 HMG 4000-000-D Um SMART-Sensoren mit dem HMG 4000 zu verbinden, wählen Sie im Startmenü die Option "**SMART-Sensoren**". Anschließend geben Sie an, mit welchem **Anschluss** der SMARTSensor verbunden ist. <chunk_seperator> Entfernen Sie die Versorgungsleitung vom elektrischen Anschluss des HYDACLAB und schrauben Sie den Adapter "ZBE 46" auf den Sensor. 

Verbinden Sie einen der Eingänge A bis D des HMG 4000 mittels eines Sensorkabels 
"ZBE 30-xx" mit dem Anschluss des Adapters "ZBE 46" 13.3 CMWIN Speziell entwickelte PC-Software, die mittels Kommunikationsbrücke (HMG 510 oder HMG 4000) mit dem HYDACLAB kommuniziert. Mit der Software können Messkurven zum PC 
übertragen, gespeichert, angezeigt und bearbeitet oder die aktuellen Messwerte dargestellt werden. Die CMWIN ist Teil des Lieferumfanges des HMG 510 und HMG 4000 bzw. steht auf der Homepage als Download bereit. 13.4 CSI B2 Mit Hilfe des Condition Monitoring Schnittstellenmoduls CSI-B-2 und der Software CMWIN ist es möglich, die Daten und Messwerte des Sensors direkt auszulesen oder die Parameter einzustellen. 

## Anmerkung

Auf unserer Homepage stehen Ihnen unsere HYDAC Software-Produkte zum Downloaden zur Verfügung.

Question:  What is the primary function of the HMG 4000 device?
output: The primary function of the HMG 4000 device is to serve as a mobile handheld measuring instrument equipped with a full-graphic color display for the visualization and recording of measurement data. It is designed to work in conjunction with the HYDACLAB to display current measurement values and stored measurement curves on its display. Additionally, the HMG 4000 allows for the editing of these recordings and can perform a reset of the HYDACLAB. The device also facilitates the connection and management of SMART sensors, enabling users to view sensor information, current measurement values, and manage long-term recordings. The HMG 4000 can be connected to a PC using the CMWIN software for further data transfer, storage, display, and editing of measurement curves.

Das HMG 4000 ist ein mobiles Handmessgerät mit einem vollgrafikfähigen Farbdisplay zur Messwertanzeige bzw. Messwertaufzeichnung. In Verbindung mit dem HMG 4000 können die aktuellen Messwerte des HYDACLAB sowie die gespeicherten Messkurven auf dem Display des HMG 4000 angezeigt werden. Diese Aufnahmen können mit dem HMG 4000 auch bearbeitet werden. Ferner kann über das HMG 4000 ein Reset des HYDACLAB vorgenommen werden. 

(genaue Beschreibung siehe Bedienungsanleitung HMG 4000). Bestell-Nr.: 925281 HMG 4000-000-D Um SMART-Sensoren mit dem HMG 4000 zu verbinden, wählen Sie im Startmenü die Option "**SMART-Sensoren**". Anschließend geben Sie an, mit welchem **Anschluss** der SMARTSensor verbunden ist. <chunk_seperator> Entfernen Sie die Versorgungsleitung vom elektrischen Anschluss des HYDACLAB und schrauben Sie den Adapter "ZBE 46" auf den Sensor. 

Verbinden Sie einen der Eingänge A bis D des HMG 4000 mittels eines Sensorkabels 
"ZBE 30-xx" mit dem Anschluss des Adapters "ZBE 46" 13.3 CMWIN Speziell entwickelte PC-Software, die mittels Kommunikationsbrücke (HMG 510 oder HMG 4000) mit dem HYDACLAB kommuniziert. Mit der Software können Messkurven zum PC 
übertragen, gespeichert, angezeigt und bearbeitet oder die aktuellen Messwerte dargestellt werden. Die CMWIN ist Teil des Lieferumfanges des HMG 510 und HMG 4000 bzw. steht auf der Homepage als Download bereit. 13.4 CSI B2 Mit Hilfe des Condition Monitoring Schnittstellenmoduls CSI-B-2 und der Software CMWIN ist es möglich, die Daten und Messwerte des Sensors direkt auszulesen oder die Parameter einzustellen.

Question:  How can users connect SMART-Sensors to the HMG 4000?
output:
To connect SMART-Sensors to the HMG 4000, users should follow these steps:

1. **Access the Start Menu**: Turn on the HMG 4000 and navigate to the start menu.

2. **Select SMART-Sensors Option**: In the start menu, choose the option labeled "**SMART-Sensoren**".

3. **Specify the Connection Port**: Indicate which connection port the SMART-Sensor is connected to. The HMG 4000 has multiple input ports (A to D), so select the appropriate one.

4. **Optional Bus Address**: Optionally, you can specify a **Sensor-Busadresse** (sensor bus address). By default, the setting is "**Ohne Adresse**" (without address). Assigning a bus address is necessary if the SMART-Sensor is to be operated within a bus system.

5. **Establish Connection**: After specifying the connection details, select "**Verbindung herstellen**" (establish connection). This action will connect the SMART-Sensor to the HMG 4000.

6. **View Sensor Information**: Once connected, the HMG 4000 will display some information about the connected SMART-Sensor above the function bar. This includes details such as the material number, serial number, and information about the various measurement channels, including their type and measurement range.

7. **Manage Sensor Data**: Users can then navigate through the main menu of the SMART-Sensor to manage and customize the sensor settings according to their needs. This includes viewing current measurement values, managing long-term recordings, and adjusting sensor parameters.

By following these steps, users can effectively connect and configure SMART-Sensors with the HMG 4000, allowing them to monitor and record various measurements as needed.

In diesem Menü können Sie Langzeitaufnahmen, die der SMART-Sensor erstellt hat, zum HMG 4000 übertragen oder diese aus dem Speicher des SMART-Sensors löschen. In Sensoreinstellungen können Sie die Parameter des Gerätes Ihren Anforderungen anpassen, siehe Kap.5.4. 13.2.1 Anschluss an ein HMG 4000 <chunk_seperator> ***** Only usable in combination with a digital input from groups *IO_ADC_00 ... IO_ADC_23,* IO_PWD_00 ... IO_PWD_05, IO_DO_00 ... IO_DO_15 or IO_PVG_00 ... IO_PVG_07.

## Hs Pwm Output:

The I/O driver's diagnostic module continuously compares the desired output duty cycle and frequency with the feedback measurements, thus allowing to reliably detect failures within the PWM output stages. This measure is active for every PWM high side output that is initialized as safety-critical and will trigger an error callback in case of dangerous failures. Due to their superior diagnostic capabilities, the system integrator is advised to use the PWM output mode rather than the digital output mode for safety-critical applications, even if the corresponding actuators are only operated statically. This can be achieved by implementing a pseude-digital mode, that only changes between minimum and maximum output duty cycles.

Question:  What information is provided in the Sensorinformationen menu of the SMART-Sensor?
output:
The Sensorinformationen menu of the SMART-Sensor provides the following information about the connected SMART-Sensor:

1. **Material Number**: This is likely a unique identifier or part number for the sensor, which helps in identifying the specific model or type of sensor being used.

2. **Serial Number**: This is a unique number assigned to each individual sensor, which can be used for tracking, warranty, and service purposes.

3. **Information on Various Measurement Channels**: This includes details about the different channels the sensor uses for measurements. It provides information on the type of measurements each channel performs and the measurement range for each channel.

This menu is essential for users to understand the specific details and capabilities of the connected SMART-Sensor, ensuring they can effectively utilize and manage the sensor's functionalities.

Question:  What can users do in the Sensor-Aufnahmen Verwalten menu?
output:
In the "Sensor-Aufnahmen Verwalten" menu, users have several options for managing long-term recordings created by the SMART-Sensor. Specifically, they can:

1. **Transfer Recordings**: Users can transfer long-term recordings from the SMART-Sensor to the HMG 4000 device.
2. **Delete Recordings**: Users have the option to delete recordings from the SMART-Sensor's memory.
3. **Check for New Recordings**: By selecting the "Aktualisieren" option, users can check if there are any new recordings available.
4. **Manage Recording Storage**: After selecting a recording and choosing the "Übertragen" option, users can decide whether to store the selected recording under the previously displayed combination of name and number in the HMG 4000 or to assign a new linkage.

These functionalities allow users to effectively manage and organize the data collected by the SMART-Sensor, ensuring that important recordings are transferred and stored appropriately while also maintaining the sensor's memory by deleting unnecessary recordings.

## Sensor-Aufnahmen Verwalten

In diesem Menü können Sie Langzeitaufnahmen, die der SMART-Sensor erstellt hat, zum HMG 4000 übertragen oder diese aus dem Speicher des SMART-Sensors löschen. Mit "**Aktualisieren**" wird geprüft, ob neue Aufnahmen vorhanden sind. Nach Auswahl einer Aufnahme und der Option "**Übertragen**" erhalten Sie eine Ansicht, in der Sie festlegen können, ob die ausgewählte Aufnahme unter der zuvor angezeigten Kombination aus Namen und Nummer im HMG 4000 abgelegt werden soll oder eine neue Verknüpfung vergeben werden soll.

IO_ADC_23,* IO_PWD_00 ... IO_PWD_05, IO_DO_00 ... IO_DO_15 or IO_PVG_00 ... IO_PVG_07.

## Hs Pwm Output:

The I/O driver's diagnostic module continuously compares the desired output duty cycle and frequency with the feedback measurements, thus allowing to reliably detect failures within the PWM output stages. This measure is active for every PWM high side output that is initialized as safety-critical and will trigger an error callback in case of dangerous failures. Due to their superior diagnostic capabilities, the system integrator is advised to use the PWM output mode rather than the digital output mode for safety-critical applications, even if the corresponding actuators are only operated statically. This can be achieved by implementing a pseude-digital mode, that only changes between minimum and maximum output duty cycles.

In Verbindung mit dem HMG 4000 können die aktuellen Messwerte des HYDACLAB sowie die gespeicherten Messkurven auf dem Display des HMG 4000 angezeigt werden. Diese Aufnahmen können mit dem HMG 4000 auch bearbeitet werden. Ferner kann über das HMG 4000 ein Reset des HYDACLAB vorgenommen werden.

Question:  What is the purpose of the CMWIN software in relation to the HMG 4000 and HYDACLAB?
output:
The CMWIN software is specifically designed to facilitate communication between the HYDACLAB sensor and a PC through the HMG 510 or HMG 4000 devices. Its primary purposes include:

1. **Data Transfer**: The software allows for the transfer of measurement curves from the HYDACLAB sensor to a PC. This enables users to store and manage their data more effectively.

2. **Data Display and Analysis**: Once the data is transferred to the PC, CMWIN can display the measurement curves, allowing users to visualize the data. This is crucial for analyzing trends and making informed decisions based on the sensor readings.

3. **Data Editing**: Users can edit the measurement curves within the software. This feature is useful for refining data, correcting errors, or preparing the data for further analysis or reporting.

4. **Real-Time Data Monitoring**: CMWIN can also display the current measurement values from the HYDACLAB sensor in real-time. This is beneficial for monitoring ongoing processes and ensuring that the system is functioning within desired parameters.

5. **Parameter Adjustment**: The software allows users to adjust the parameters of the HYDACLAB sensor. This capability is essential for customizing the sensor settings to meet specific monitoring requirements or to optimize performance.

Overall, CMWIN enhances the functionality of the HMG 4000 and HYDACLAB by providing a comprehensive tool for data management, analysis, and sensor configuration.

## 15 Wichtige Hinweise Auf Einen Blick

 Der montierte Sensor muss vollständig in das Medium eintauchen, damit dieses frei durch den Sensor zirkulieren kann.

 Achten Sie beim Einbau ohne den Montageblock ZBM 21 darauf, dass das Einströmen des Mediums durch den Einbau nicht beeinträchtigt wird. Zwischen der Stirnseite des Sensorkopfes und der gegenüberliegenden Rohr- bzw. Gehäusewand muss ein Mindestabstand von 10 mm eingehalten werden.

 Stellen Sie einen stetigen Durchfluss sicher und vermeiden Sie die Bildung von Luftblasen. Bei stehendem Öl sind erhöhte Messabweichungen möglich.

 Grundsätzlich ist HYDACLAB nur dann mit Spannung zu versorgen, wenn normaler Volumenstrom gewährleistet ist. D.h. trennen Sie das HYDACLAB von der Spannungsversorgung sobald die Anlage abgeschaltet wird, außer Betrieb geht oder eine zeitlich nennenswerte Unterbrechung des Volumenstromes eintritt. <chunk_seperator> ## Pour Le Raccordement Au Bus Can Uniquement : Taux De Bauds Can [Kbit]

## 2 Safety Information

The Fluid Condition Sensor HYDACLAB® presents no safety concerns when operated in accordance with this user manual. However, in order to avoid any risk to the operator or any damage due to incorrect handling of the unit, please adhere strictly to the following safety instructions: 
 Before commissioning, check that the unit is in perfect condition.

 Before commissioning, please read the operating instructions. Ensure that the unit is suitable for your application.

 During transportation, extra care must be taken to protect the unit from vibration and shock.

 The HYDACLAB must not be put into service if any known technical defects are apparent. The unit must be installed according to the instructions.
Question:  What must be ensured about the HYDACLAB sensor during installation to allow free circulation of the medium?
output: During the installation of the HYDACLAB sensor, it is crucial to ensure that the sensor is fully immersed in the medium to allow free circulation through the sensor. Additionally, if the installation is done without the mounting block ZBM 21, care must be taken to ensure that the inflow of the medium is not obstructed by the installation. A minimum distance of 10 mm must be maintained between the front face of the sensor head and the opposite wall of the pipe or housing. This setup is essential to ensure a steady flow and to avoid the formation of air bubbles, which can lead to increased measurement deviations, especially in stationary oil conditions.

Question:  What is the minimum distance that must be maintained between the sensor head and the opposite wall of the pipe or housing?
output: The minimum distance that must be maintained between the sensor head and the opposite wall of the pipe or housing is 10 mm. This ensures that the inflow of the medium is not obstructed and allows for proper circulation through the sensor.

The application software **shall** not perform any I/O handling in the error callback or notification callback function with exception of the following functions:
- *IO_RTC_GetDateAndTimeStatus*
- *IO_RTC_GetDateAndTime*
- *IO_EEPROM_GetStatus*
- *IO_EEPROM_Read*
- *IO_EEPROM_Write* Category: Requirement Label: Error_Diagnostics ID: 609587 Related To: 626893 Related To':
Upon activation of the safe state, the application software **shall** save the error code that has caused the safe state in a non-volatile failure memory, e.g. the EEPROM.

Category: Requirement Label: Startup_Failure_Memory ID: 717487 Related To: 626899 Related To':
Upon start-up, the application software **shall** check the failure memory's last entries and instruct the Main CPU to enter the safe state, if the last entries show fatal errors that might prevent a safe system operation, e.g. a failing Main CPU, watchdog or voltage monitor.

- <chunk_seperator> Canaux A à H : 
- **Reconnaissance automatique pour les capteurs HSI** 
(pression, température et débit et capteurs SMART) 
- **Branchement des capteurs usuels avec signaux de courant et de tension** 
- **Canaux différentiels pour les canaux A - B ; canal C - D ; canal différentiel pour le** 
diaphragme de mesure du débit (représentation au niveau du canal B) 
Canaux I et J : 
- **Canaux de fréquence (vitesse de rotation, comptage)** 
Plage de fréquence : 1 .. 30 000 Hz (≤ ± **0,1 % FS max.)** 
Commutation (niveau haut/bas) : 2 V/1 V Tension d'entrée max. : 50 V ; retard à l'affichage **max. 2 s** <chunk_seperator> ## 14 Lieferumfang

1 HYDACLAB - Sensor 1 Bedienungsanleitung 

## 15 Wichtige Hinweise Auf Einen Blick

 Der montierte Sensor muss vollständig in das Medium eintauchen, damit dieses frei durch den Sensor zirkulieren kann.

 Achten Sie beim Einbau ohne den Montageblock ZBM 21 darauf, dass das Einströmen des Mediums durch den Einbau nicht beeinträchtigt wird. Zwischen der Stirnseite des Sensorkopfes und der gegenüberliegenden Rohr- bzw. Gehäusewand muss ein Mindestabstand von 10 mm eingehalten werden.

 Stellen Sie einen stetigen Durchfluss sicher und vermeiden Sie die Bildung von Luftblasen. Bei stehendem Öl sind erhöhte Messabweichungen möglich.

 Grundsätzlich ist HYDACLAB nur dann mit Spannung zu versorgen, wenn normaler Volumenstrom gewährleistet ist. D.h. trennen Sie das HYDACLAB von der Spannungsversorgung sobald die Anlage abgeschaltet wird, außer Betrieb geht oder eine zeitlich nennenswerte Unterbrechung des Volumenstromes eintritt. <chunk_seperator> ## Pour Le Raccordement Au Bus Can Uniquement : Taux De Bauds Can [Kbit] 

![34_Image_1.Png](34_Image_1.Png)

Le point de menu « Taux de bauds CAN [kBit] » vous permet de prescrire entre 10 à 1 000 kBit le taux de bauds nécessaire du réseau CAN auquel l'appareil HMG 3010 doit être raccordé. Toutes les possibilités de réglage et la manipulation pour le mode « CAN-Bus » figurent au chapitre 6.5 « Fonctions CAN ». 

## 6.1.5 Gestion Des Configurations (Sauvegarder, Charger...)

Tous les réglages des canaux de mesure

## 2 Safety Information

The Fluid Condition Sensor HYDACLAB® presents no safety concerns when operated in accordance with this user manual. However, in order to avoid any risk to the operator or any damage due to incorrect handling of the unit, please adhere strictly to the following safety instructions: 
 Before commissioning, check that the unit is in perfect condition.

 Before commissioning, please read the operating instructions. Ensure that the unit is suitable for your application.

 During transportation, extra care must be taken to protect the unit from vibration and shock.

 The HYDACLAB must not be put into service if any known technical defects are apparent. The unit must be installed according to the instructions.
Question:  Under what conditions should the HYDACLAB sensor be disconnected from the power supply?
output:
The HYDACLAB sensor should be disconnected from the power supply under the following conditions:

1. **When the system is shut down**: If the entire system or installation where the HYDACLAB sensor is used is turned off, the sensor should also be disconnected from the power supply.

2. **When the system is out of operation**: If the system is not in use or is temporarily out of operation, the sensor should be disconnected to prevent any unnecessary power consumption or potential damage.

3. **During significant interruptions in flow**: If there is a notable interruption in the volume flow of the medium being measured, the sensor should be disconnected. This is because the HYDACLAB sensor is designed to operate with a normal volume flow, and interruptions can lead to inaccurate measurements or potential damage to the sensor.

These precautions ensure that the sensor operates correctly and is protected from conditions that could lead to measurement errors or damage.

Question:  What should be avoided during the reference cycle of the HYDACLAB sensor?
output:
During the reference cycle of the HYDACLAB sensor, the following should be avoided:

1. **Fluid Mixing**: Avoid any mixing of different fluids during the reference cycle. This ensures that the sensor can accurately calibrate itself based on a consistent fluid composition.

2. **Adding New Oil**: Do not add new oil to the system during the reference cycle. Introducing new oil can alter the fluid properties and lead to inaccurate calibration.

These precautions are necessary to ensure that the sensor operates under typical operating conditions and can accurately measure and monitor the fluid's condition.

 The HYDACLAB must not be put into service if any known technical defects are apparent. The unit must be installed according to the instructions.
Question:  Under what circumstances is the liability of the manufacturer limited according to the user manual?
output:
The liability of the manufacturer is limited under several specific circumstances according to the user manual:

1. **General Exclusion of Liability**: The manufacturer excludes liability for any errors in the user manual, despite their best efforts to ensure accuracy. This general exclusion applies to all types of claims, regardless of the legal basis.

2. **Exclusion of Liability for Financial Losses**: The manufacturer specifically excludes liability for lost profits or other financial damages.

3. **Exceptions to the Exclusion**:
   - **Intentional Misconduct or Gross Negligence**: The liability exclusion does not apply in cases of intentional misconduct or gross negligence by the manufacturer.
   - **Fraudulent Concealment of Defects**: If the manufacturer has fraudulently concealed defects, the exclusion does not apply.
   - **Guaranteed Absence of Defects**: If the manufacturer has guaranteed the absence of defects, the exclusion does not apply.
   - **Injury to Life, Body, or Health**: The exclusion does not apply in cases of culpable injury to life, body, or health.

4. **Breach of Essential Contractual Obligations**: If the manufacturer negligently breaches an essential contractual obligation, their liability is limited to foreseeable damages.

5. **Product Liability Claims**: Claims arising from product liability laws remain unaffected by the liability exclusion.

6. **Validity of the German Original Manual**: In case of translations, the German original manual is the only valid text, implying that any discrepancies in translations do not affect the liability terms as stated in the original German manual.

## 5 Function

HYDACLAB® is a compact, multi-functional sensor for determining the online condition of oil. The user is kept informed of changes in fluid condition as they occur and can take immediate action in the case of deteriorating operating conditions. Changes in fluid condition that might occur due to ageing or mixing with other fluids, for example, are indicated by measuring the temperature, the saturation level, the relative change in electrical conductivity and the relative change in dielectric constant (also referred to as DC). <chunk_seperator> The cable shielding must be fitted by qualified personnel, subject to the ambient conditions and with the aim of suppressing interference.

- Standard brushed DC-motors with defined power rating - Motors with end position switches and diodes for rotation direction dependent automatic stop at full excursion.

- Motors with integrated electronic control (including brushless DC-motors) up to a well-defined current limit and a maximum input capacitance.

Motors running at different speed by using different windings are not supported.

Question:  What must be done after an oil change when using the HYDACLAB sensor?
output: After an oil change, it is essential to perform a RESET on the HYDACLAB sensor. This step is crucial because the sensor should not be commissioned in old oil, as all relative data changes will be invalid. Resetting the sensor ensures that it accurately measures and monitors the condition of the new oil, providing reliable data on parameters such as temperature, saturation level, electrical conductivity, and dielectric constant.

Question:  How should the HYDACLAB sensor be installed in the hydraulic system to ensure proper functionality?
output:
To ensure proper functionality, the HYDACLAB sensor must be installed in the hydraulic system following these detailed guidelines:

1. **Technical Condition**: Ensure that the HYDACLAB sensor is free from any known technical defects before installation. Do not put the sensor into service if any defects are apparent.

2. **Type Code Label**: Note the information on the type code label before installation.

3. **Oil Condition**: The sensor should not be commissioned in old oil. After an oil change, a RESET must be carried out to ensure all relative data changes are valid.

4. **Installation Position**:
   - The sensor can be installed directly in the hydraulic system via the threaded G ¾ connection.
   - It is recommended to fit the sensor in an inclined position with a fitting angle of at least 30°.
   - Avoid fitting the sensor vertically with the sensor element pointing downwards.
   - Ensure the sensor is completely submerged in the fluid and that the fluid can circulate freely through the sensor.

5. **Oil Flow Rate**: The maximum oil flow rate should not exceed 5 m/s to ensure accurate readings and proper sensor operation.

6. **Mounting Accessories**: Use the appropriate mounting accessories provided by HYDAC ELECTRONIC (refer to section 12.1, Mechanical Accessories).

7. **Electrical Connection**:
   - The electrical connection must be carried out by a qualified electrician according to the relevant regulations of the country (e.g., VDE 0100 in Germany).
   - Ensure the sensor's housing is correctly earthed by a qualified electrician. When installed in a hydraulic block, earthing the block via the hydraulic system is sufficient.

8. **Electromagnetic Interference**:
   - Keep cable connections as short as possible.
   - Use shielded cable (e.g., LIYCY 5 x 0.5 mm²) to minimize interference.
   - The cable shielding must be fitted by qualified personnel, considering the ambient conditions and aiming to suppress interference.
   - Keep the unit well away from electrical supply lines of power equipment and any electrical or electronic equipment that can cause interference.

By adhering to these installation guidelines, the HYDACLAB sensor will function correctly, providing accurate and reliable data on the condition of the oil in the hydraulic system.

Question:  What are the recommended practices to reduce the effect of electromagnetic interference when installing the HYDACLAB sensor?
output:
To reduce the effect of electromagnetic interference when installing the HYDACLAB sensor, the following practices are recommended:

1. **Keep Cable Connections Short**: Ensure that the cable connections are as short as possible. This minimizes the potential for electromagnetic interference to affect the signal.

2. **Use Shielded Cable**: Utilize shielded cables, such as LIYCY 5 x 0.5 mm², to protect the signal from external electromagnetic interference.

3. **Proper Cable Shielding**: The cable shielding must be installed by qualified personnel. The installation should take into account the ambient conditions and aim to suppress interference effectively.

4. **Avoid Proximity to Electrical Supply Lines**: Position the HYDACLAB sensor well away from the electrical supply lines of power equipment. This helps to prevent interference from high-power electrical currents.

5. **Distance from Interfering Equipment**: Keep the sensor away from any electrical or electronic equipment that can cause interference. This includes devices that emit strong electromagnetic fields.

By following these practices, the integrity of the sensor's measurements can be maintained, ensuring accurate monitoring of the oil condition.

## 5 Function

HYDACLAB® is a compact, multi-functional sensor for determining the online condition of oil. The user is kept informed of changes in fluid condition as they occur and can take immediate action in the case of deteriorating operating conditions. Changes in fluid condition that might occur due to ageing or mixing with other fluids, for example, are indicated by measuring the temperature, the saturation level, the relative change in electrical conductivity and the relative change in dielectric constant (also referred to as DC). <chunk_seperator> The cable shielding must be fitted by qualified personnel, subject to the ambient conditions and with the aim of suppressing interference.

Question:  What does the term "relative dielectric constant" refer to in the context of the HYDACLAB sensor's operating manual?
output:
In the context of the HYDACLAB sensor's operating manual, the term "relative dielectric constant" refers to a parameter that measures the permeability of a substance to electrical fields in comparison to the permeability of a vacuum. This parameter is crucial for understanding how the substance (in this case, oil) interacts with electrical fields. The relative dielectric constant is also known by other terms such as "relative permittivity," "permittivity value," or simply "dielectric value." 

The manual further explains that the relative dielectric constant will be referred to as DC. Additionally, the manual introduces the concept of the relative change in the dielectric constant, which is the relative change in DC. This measurement is important for monitoring the condition of the oil, as changes in the dielectric constant can indicate alterations in the oil's properties due to factors like ageing or contamination.

The HYDACLAB sensor uses this parameter, along with other measurements such as temperature, saturation level, and electrical conductivity, to provide a comprehensive assessment of the oil's condition. This allows users to detect and respond to changes in the fluid's state, ensuring optimal performance and preventing potential damage to the hydraulic system.

Question:  What parameters does the HYDACLAB sensor measure to determine the online condition of oil?
output:
The HYDACLAB sensor measures several key parameters to determine the online condition of oil. These parameters include:

1. **Temperature**: The sensor monitors the temperature of the oil, which is crucial for understanding the operating conditions and potential thermal degradation of the oil.

2. **Saturation Level**: This parameter indicates the concentration of water in the oil. It is displayed relatively in percentage terms, where 100% corresponds to the oil being fully saturated with water, meaning no more water can be dissolved and free water will be present in the oil.

3. **Relative Change in Electrical Conductivity**: The sensor measures the electrical conductivity of the oil in nS/m and tracks changes in this conductivity. This can provide insights into the presence of contaminants or degradation products in the oil.

4. **Relative Change in Dielectric Constant (DC)**: The dielectric constant is a measure of the oil's ability to store electrical energy in an electric field. The sensor measures the relative change in this constant, which can indicate changes in the oil's composition due to ageing, contamination, or mixing with other fluids.

By monitoring these parameters, the HYDACLAB sensor provides a comprehensive overview of the oil's condition, allowing users to take immediate action if any deteriorating conditions are detected.

Another line is labeled "oil aging," which could refer to the natural degradation of the oil over time. <chunk_seperator> ## 7.2.3 Diagnostic State Machine Error Codes

Details about the errors of the diagnostic state machine. The following table gives an overview of the error codes and their types.

There are **four types of errors**:
- **Persistent fatal errors**
If a fatal error is detected, the diagnostic state machine always activates the safe state. The application will be informed about the error before a reset occurs (via the notification callback, see **DIAG_NOTIFY_CB).**
- **Persistent non-fatal errors**
For non-fatal errors the application can decide which action to take (via the error callback, see DIAG_ERROR_CB).

- **Temporary fatal errors**
For these errors a glitch filter (de-bounce) is implemented, **which means that they are reported** after the configured anti-glitch time. After the glitch filter time has expired, the error will be treated like a persistent fatal error.

Question:  What information do the LEDs displayed by HYDACLAB indicate?
output:
The LEDs displayed by HYDACLAB provide crucial information regarding the measured values of both analogue and switching signals. Specifically, they indicate:

1. **Warning and Alarm Signals**: The LEDs show whether a warning or alarm condition has been triggered. This is particularly important for monitoring the oil condition and ensuring that any deviations from the norm are promptly addressed.

2. **Sensor Status**: The LEDs provide information about the operational status of the sensor. This can help in diagnosing any issues with the sensor itself, ensuring that it is functioning correctly and providing accurate readings.

3. **Oil Condition**: The LEDs also give insights into the condition of the oil being monitored. This includes changes in the oil's dielectric constant, conductivity, saturation level, and temperature, which are critical parameters for assessing the oil's quality and performance.

In summary, the LEDs serve as a visual indicator for real-time monitoring of the oil's condition, sensor status, and any warning or alarm conditions that may arise, ensuring that the system operates within safe and optimal parameters.

Question:  What happens when the switching output (normally closed function as standard version PIN 2) detects a change in the oil condition?
output:
When the switching output (normally closed function as standard version PIN 2) detects a change in the oil condition, it initiates an alarm function. This alarm function is triggered based on specific changes in the measured values of the oil condition. The default settings for these changes are as follows:

1. **Relative change in dielectric constant**: ± 15%
2. **Relative change in conductivity**: ± 15%
3. **Saturation level**: ≥ 85%
4. **Temperature**: ≥ 80°C

These thresholds indicate that if any of these parameters deviate from their reference values by the specified amounts, the switching output will activate the alarm. This alarm serves as a warning that the oil condition has changed significantly and may require attention or intervention to maintain the proper functioning of the system.

Question:  How are the analogue output signals represented and output sequentially on PIN 4?
output:
The analogue output signals on PIN 4 are represented and output sequentially in a specific order and format. These signals are designed to provide detailed information about various measured values related to the oil condition. Here is a detailed breakdown of how these signals are represented and output:

1. **Signal Representation**:
   - All signals are default set as 4..20 mA current-loop signals. This means that the current in the loop varies between 4 mA and 20 mA to represent different measured values.
   - Alternatively, a 0 .. 10V signal output is also possible, but the default setting is the current-loop signal.

2. **Sequential Output**:
   - The signals are output in a specific sequence, each with a defined duration and a pause between them. The sequence and spacing are as follows:

   | **Output Signal** | **Duration** |
   |-------------------|--------------|
   | Start signal      | 20 mA        |
   | Pause             | 4 mA         |
   | Signal 1: Absolute conductivity value (0 .. 100 nS/m) | 2 s |
   | Pause             | 2 s          |
   | Signal 2: Change in electrical conductivity (-100 .. 200%) | 2 s |
   | Pause             | 2 s          |
   | Signal 3: Absolute DC value (1 .. 10) | 2 s |
   | Pause             | 2 s          |
   | Signal 4: Relative Change in DC (-30% ... +30%) | 2 s |
   | Pause             | 2 s          |
   | Signal 5: Saturation level (0% ... +100%) | 2 s |
   | Pause             | 2 s          |
   | Signal 6: Temperature (-25°C... +100°C) | 2 s |
   | Pause             | 2 s          |
   | Signal 7: Status signal (See table below for levels) | 2 s |
   | Pause before next output cycle | 4 mA |

3. **Details of Each Signal**:
   - **Start Signal**: A 20 mA signal is used to indicate the beginning of the sequence.
   - **Pause**: A 4 mA signal is used as a pause between each signal to clearly separate them.
   - **Signal 1**: Represents the absolute conductivity value, ranging from 0 to 100 nS/m, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Signal 2**: Represents the change in electrical conductivity, ranging from -100% to 200%, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Signal 3**: Represents the absolute dielectric constant (DC) value, ranging from 1 to 10, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Signal 4**: Represents the relative change in DC, ranging from -30% to +30%, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Signal 5**: Represents the saturation level, ranging from 0% to 100%, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Signal 6**: Represents the temperature, ranging from -25°C to +100°C, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Signal 7**: Represents the status signal, with specific levels detailed in a table, and is output for 2 seconds.
   - **Pause Before Next Output Cycle**: A 4 mA signal is used as a pause before the next output cycle begins.

This structured and sequential output ensures that each measured value is clearly communicated and can be accurately interpreted by a connected non-HYDAC device.

Change in DC', '-30% ... +30%': '2 s'}, {'Pause (4 mA)': '2 s'}, {'Signal 5': 'Saturation level', '0% ... +100%': '2 s'}, {'Pause (4 mA)': '2 s'}, {'Signal 6': 'Temperature', '-25°C... +100°C': '2 s'}, {'Pause (4 mA)': '2 s'}, {'Signal 7': 'Status signal', 'See table below for levels': '2 s'}, {'Pause before next output cycle': '4 mA'}]</table_13>
## Hydaclab **1400 Page 5** Explanation Of Status Signal: <chunk_seperator> '-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- <chunk_seperator> With the fastscan protocol, a LSS master can identify the *LSS address* **of unknown and nonconfigured devices. In the beginning of such a requests, all non-configured devices have to** 
be in the "*LSS Waiting***" mode.** 
The inquiry will be initiated by the LSS master by a particular request ("Bit Check" = 128) in order to mark the start of the request sequence. This inquiry should be confirmed by all LSS 
devices which have not yet been configured by response "*Identify slave***". By means of this** 
response, the LSS master recognises that further LSS devices need to be configured. That is to say, the fastscan protocol performs a search for existing LSS addresses. For this purpose, all sections of the *LSS address* **are inquired bit by bit and sequentially. LSS devices** 
with matching address sections confirm the related request positively by sending the response "*Identify slave"***. If the recently inquired address section does not match, no**
Question:  What are the default pre-set signals and their durations for the sequential analogue output?
output:
The default pre-set signals for the sequential analogue output and their durations are as follows:

1. **Start signal**: 
   - **Output signal**: 20 mA
   - **Duration**: Not specified (acts as the initiation signal)

2. **Pause**: 
   - **Output signal**: 4 mA
   - **Duration**: Not specified (acts as a brief pause before the next signal)

3. **Signal 1**: 
   - **Output signal**: Absolute conductivity value (0 .. 100 nS/m)
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

4. **Pause**: 
   - **Output signal**: 4 mA
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

5. **Signal 2**: 
   - **Output signal**: Change in electrical conductivity (-100 .. 200%)
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

6. **Pause**: 
   - **Output signal**: 4 mA
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

7. **Signal 3**: 
   - **Output signal**: Absolute DC value (1 .. 10)
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

8. **Pause**: 
   - **Output signal**: 4 mA
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

9. **Signal 4**: 
   - **Output signal**: Relative change in DC (-30% ... +30%)
   - **Duration**: 2 seconds

10. **Pause**: 
    - **Output signal**: 4 mA
    - **Duration**: 2 seconds

11. **Signal 5**: 
    - **Output signal**: Saturation level (0% ... +100%)
    - **Duration**: 2 seconds

12. **Pause**: 
    - **Output signal**: 4 mA
    - **Duration**: 2 seconds

13. **Signal 6**: 
    - **Output signal**: Temperature (-25°C ... +100°C)
    - **Duration**: 2 seconds

14. **Pause**: 
    - **Output signal**: 4 mA
    - **Duration**: 2 seconds

15. **Signal 7**: 
    - **Output signal**: Status signal (specific levels are detailed in a table not provided here)
    - **Duration**: 2 seconds

16. **Pause before next output cycle**: 
    - **Output signal**: 4 mA
    - **Duration**: Not specified (acts as a pause before the sequence restarts)

Each signal is output sequentially, with a 2-second duration for each signal and a 2-second pause between signals. The start signal and the final pause before the next output cycle are also part of the sequence but their specific durations are not detailed.

Question:  What is the status signal when the current is less than 4.0 mA?
output: When the current is less than 4.0 mA, the status signal indicates an "Error." This is considered irrelevant for the operating phases and other conditions listed in the table.

Question:  At what voltage range does the operating phase start and end?
output: The operating phase starts at a voltage range of 1.25 V and ends at 2.50 V. This corresponds to a current range of 6.0 mA to 8.0 mA.

## 7.2.4.139 #Define Diag_E_Pwm_Feedback 14U <chunk_seperator> ## Timestamp Functions

- **IO_RTC_StartTime()**
- **IO_RTC_GetTimeUS()**
The function IO_RTC_StartTime() returns a timestamp. The function IO_RTC_GetTimeUS() **returns the time which has passed since the timestamp-value passed as an argument to this function.**
The application can use these two functions as often as it needs to. For different timing tasks only different timestamp variables need to be used.

## Periodic Functions

- **IO_RTC_PeriodicInit()**
- **IO_RTC_PeriodicDeInit()**
The function IO_RTC_PeriodicInit() **can be used to register a periodic callback to the provided**
function which has to be passed as an argument. The function IO_RTC_PeriodicDeInit() **will**
unregister this periodic call again.

## Real Time Clock (Date And Time) Functions <chunk_seperator> The time should be defined in order to ensure that the system carries out a complete circulation, a mixing of the oil and a complete temperature cycle.

Notice: If the temperature range is changed during the reference cycle, NO reset needs to be performed, as HYDACLAB automatically adapts to the new range. 

## 5.4.1.3 Output Scaling

In the output scaling menu you can set the upper range of operating hours, the HYDACLAB sensor thus counts the operating hours. 

The output signal for the operating hours is scaled to a value set by the user, i.e. 4mA 0 operating hours and 20 mA 10000 operating hours. This figure defines the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset. Upper range Arrhenius: The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature, the weighting is based on the Arrhenius equation. <chunk_seperator> By pressing the OK button, the value is highlighted and then it is possible to enter a new value. Please press OK again to confirm the selected value. Default settings- see opposite. 

## 5.4.1.1 Temperature Settings

Minimum operation temperature - The sensor is operational when the temperature is above this value. 

Maximum operation temperature - The sensor is operational when the temperature is below this value Reference temperature - The temperature compensated conductivity and DC values will be referenced to this temperature. 

Activating temperature - This value must be exceeded in order for the sensor to start its referencing cycle. 

Homogenisation period - The duration of the homogenisation phase will be defined by this period. 

The Homogenisation phase starts, once 50% of the working temperature range has been recorded. (see also graph chapter 6).

This could be particularly useful in applications where operations are conducted across different geographical locations or where precise timing is crucial for various processes. The clocks help ensure that the user can keep track of time-sensitive activities and manage tasks efficiently across different time zones.

Question:  How can the sensor parameters be adjusted to match application requirements?
output:
The sensor parameters can be adjusted to match application requirements using two primary methods: the HMG 4000 device and the PC software CMWIN. Here is a detailed step-by-step process for each method:

### Using the HMG 4000 Device

1. **Establish Connection**: First, establish a connection with the sensor as described in chapter 13.2 of the manual.
2. **Navigate to Main Menu**: After connecting the sensor, you will be directed to the main menu.
3. **Select Sub Menu**: Use the navigation keys "↑" or "↓" to select the sub-menu that you wish to change.
4. **Basic Settings Menu**: In the basic settings menu, you can adjust temperature settings, output scaling, and recording settings.
   - **Temperature Settings**: 
     - **Minimum Operation Temperature**: Set the minimum temperature at which the sensor is operational.
     - **Maximum Operation Temperature**: Set the maximum temperature at which the sensor is operational.
     - **Reference Temperature**: Set the temperature to which the conductivity and DC values will be referenced.
     - **Activating Temperature**: Set the temperature that must be exceeded for the sensor to start its referencing cycle.
     - **Homogenisation Period**: Define the duration of the homogenisation phase, ensuring complete circulation and mixing of the oil.
   - **Output Scaling**: 
     - Set the upper range of operating hours, scaling the output signal to a user-defined value (e.g., 4mA for 0 operating hours and 20mA for 10000 operating hours).
     - Define the Arrhenius rate for temperature-dependent operating hours, scaling the output signal accordingly (e.g., 4mA for 0 temperature-dependent operating hours and 20mA for 20000 temperature-dependent operating hours).
   - **Recording Settings**: Adjust settings related to the recording of data by the sensor.

5. **Modify Values**: Select the value to be modified using the navigation keys. Press the OK button to highlight the value, enter the new value, and press OK again to confirm the selected value.

### Using the PC Software CMWIN

1. **Establish Connection**: Connect the sensor to the PC and launch the CMWIN software.
2. **Access Setting Dialogue**: Navigate to the setting dialogue within the software.
3. **Adjust Parameters**: Use the software interface to adjust the sensor parameters, similar to the options available on the HMG 4000 device.
   - **Temperature Settings**: Adjust minimum and maximum operation temperatures, reference temperature, activating temperature, and homogenisation period.
   - **Output Scaling**: Set the upper range of operating hours and define the Arrhenius rate for temperature-dependent operating hours.
   - **Recording Settings**: Configure the recording settings as needed.

By following these steps, you can effectively adjust the sensor parameters to match the specific requirements of your application, ensuring optimal performance and accurate data collection.

## 5.4.1.3 Output Scaling

In the output scaling menu you can set the upper range of operating hours, the HYDACLAB sensor thus counts the operating hours. 

The output signal for the operating hours is scaled to a value set by the user, i.e. 4mA 0 operating hours and 20 mA 10000 operating hours. This figure defines the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset. Please press OK again to confirm the selected value. Default settings- see opposite. 

## 5.4.1.1 Temperature Settings

Minimum operation temperature - The sensor is operational when the temperature is above this value. 

Maximum operation temperature - The sensor is operational when the temperature is below this value Reference temperature - The temperature compensated conductivity and DC values will be referenced to this temperature. 

Activating temperature - This value must be exceeded in order for the sensor to start its referencing cycle. 

Homogenisation period - The duration of the homogenisation phase will be defined by this period. 

The Homogenisation phase starts, once 50% of the working temperature range has been recorded. (see also graph chapter 6).
Question:  What settings can be changed in the basic settings menu?
output:
In the basic settings menu, the following settings can be changed:

1. **Temperature Settings**:
   - **Minimum Operation Temperature**: The sensor is operational when the temperature is above this value.
   - **Maximum Operation Temperature**: The sensor is operational when the temperature is below this value.
   - **Reference Temperature**: The temperature to which the temperature-compensated conductivity and DC values will be referenced.
   - **Activating Temperature**: This value must be exceeded for the sensor to start its referencing cycle.
   - **Homogenisation Period**: The duration of the homogenisation phase, which starts once 50% of the working temperature range has been recorded. This period should ensure complete circulation, mixing of the oil, and a complete temperature cycle.

2. **Output Scaling**:
   - **Upper Range of Operating Hours**: The HYDACLAB sensor counts the operating hours, and the output signal for these hours is scaled to a user-defined value (e.g., 4 mA for 0 operating hours and 20 mA for 10,000 operating hours). This figure defines the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset.
   - **Upper Range Arrhenius**: The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature, based on the Arrhenius equation. The output signal is scaled to an upper value set by the user (e.g., 4 mA for 0 temperature-dependent operating hours and 20 mA for 20,000 temperature-dependent operating hours). This value defines the maximum expected oil service life in the system.

3. **Recording Settings**:
   - Specific details about the recording settings are not provided in the context, but it is implied that various parameters related to data recording can be adjusted in this menu.

These settings allow users to tailor the sensor's operation to match specific application requirements, ensuring optimal performance and accurate data collection.

## 5.4.1.4 Recording Settings <chunk_seperator> The Homogenisation phase starts, once 50% of the working temperature range has been recorded. (see also graph chapter 6).

The time should be defined in order to ensure that the system carries out a complete circulation, a mixing of the oil and a complete temperature cycle. <chunk_seperator> Overall, the image provides a clear visual explanation of various terms and concepts related to temperature, making it an informative reference for understanding these concepts better.) Notice: If the temperature range is changed during the reference cycle, NO reset needs to be performed, as HYDACLAB automatically adapts to the new range. 

## 5.4.1.3 Output Scaling

In the output scaling menu you can set the upper range of operating hours, the HYDACLAB sensor thus counts the operating hours. 

The output signal for the operating hours is scaled to a value set by the user, i.e. 4mA 0 operating hours and 20 mA 10000 operating hours. This figure defines the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset. Upper range Arrhenius: The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature, the weighting is based on the Arrhenius equation. <chunk_seperator> By pressing the OK button, the value is highlighted and then it is possible to enter a new value. Please press OK again to confirm the selected value. Default settings- see opposite. 

## 5.4.1.1 Temperature Settings

Minimum operation temperature - The sensor is operational when the temperature is above this value. 

Maximum operation temperature - The sensor is operational when the temperature is below this value Reference temperature - The temperature compensated conductivity and DC values will be referenced to this temperature. 

Activating temperature - This value must be exceeded in order for the sensor to start its referencing cycle. 

Homogenisation period - The duration of the homogenisation phase will be defined by this period. 

The Homogenisation phase starts, once 50% of the working temperature range has been recorded. (see also graph chapter 6).
Question:  What does the Arrhenius rate define in the output scaling menu?
output:
The Arrhenius rate in the output scaling menu defines the operating hours depending on temperature. The weighting is based on the Arrhenius equation, which is a formula used to express the temperature dependence of reaction rates. In this context, it is used to determine the temperature-dependent operating hours of the system. 

The output signal for the Arrhenius value is scaled to an upper value set by the user. For example, a 4 mA signal corresponds to 0 temperature-dependent operating hours, while a 20 mA signal corresponds to 20,000 temperature-dependent operating hours. This value essentially defines the maximum expected oil service life in the system, taking into account the effects of temperature on the operating hours.

Question:  What values are stored in the recording settings?
output:
In the recording settings, the following values are stored:

1. Absolute conductivity
2. Absolute DC (Direct Current)
3. Current temperature
4. Minimum temperature values
5. Maximum temperature values
6. Saturation level

These values are recorded at intervals adjustable by the user, ranging from 10 seconds to 2 hours. The data storage system has three levels, and if the storage space is exhausted, data sets are compressed and moved to the next level. The stored values can be retained for up to 10 years.

Question:  How can the analogue output signal be configured in the HYDACLAB output functions?
output:
In the HYDACLAB output functions, the analogue output signal can be configured through the following steps:

1. **Accessing the Output Functions:**
   - Navigate to the sub-menu **Output 2** within the HYDACLAB interface.

2. **Configuring the Analogue Output:**
   - In the **analogue output** section, you can select the parameters that you want to display.
   - You have the option to set the analogue output signal to either a 0 - 10 V signal or a 4 - 20 mA signal.

3. **Parameter Selection:**
   - The user can choose which parameters to display. If no parameter is selected, the analogue output is switched off.
   - If only one parameter is selected, a pure analogue signal is output without any sequence.

4. **Sequence Configuration:**
   - If multiple parameters are selected, the values are shown in a sequence. Each parameter is displayed for 2 seconds, followed by a 2-second pause.
   - The sequence starts with a 100% value representing the start value, followed by a 32-second pause. This results in a sequence length of 30 seconds for 7 values plus the start value.
   - The sequence restarts every 62 seconds.

5. **Special Parameters:**
   - For the Arrhenius value and the operating hours, the output signal is scaled to a maximum value set by the user.
   - For other parameters, the measuring ranges are set to default settings.

6. **Output Values for Oil Condition:**
   - The output values for the oil condition are represented as follows:
     - 0%: No statement can be made
     - 25%: OK
     - 50%: Warning
     - 75%: Quick oil change
     - 100%: Alert

By following these steps, you can effectively configure the analogue output signal in the HYDACLAB output functions to meet your specific requirements.

Question:  What happens if no parameter is selected for the analogue output in HYDACLAB?
output: If no parameter is selected for the analogue output in HYDACLAB, the analogue output is switched off. This means that the system will not generate any analogue signal, as there are no parameters chosen to be displayed or measured. The analogue output function relies on the selection of parameters to generate and output signals, and without any selected parameters, it remains inactive.

Question:  How are the switch points defined and displayed in the HYDACLAB switching outputs?
output:
In the HYDACLAB switching outputs, switch points are defined and displayed through a combination of bit coding and logical expressions. Here is a detailed explanation of the process:

1. **Bit Coding to Device Status**: The switch points are bit coded to the device status. This means that each switch point is associated with a specific bit in the device's status register, which indicates whether the switch point is active or not.

2. **Physical Switching Output**: The switch points can also be issued via a physical switching output. This allows the device to interact with external systems or components by sending a physical signal when a switch point is activated.

3. **Analogue Sequence Display**: The switch points are displayed in the analogue sequence, as described in section 5.2. This means that the status of the switch points is included in the sequence of output values that are shown one after another, with each parameter being displayed for 2 seconds followed by a 2-second pause.

4. **Switching Function Definition**: For each switch point, a switching function can be defined. This function determines the conditions under which the switch point will be activated or deactivated. The switching function is defined by a logical expression, which is entered in the form of a text.

5. **Logical Expressions**: The logical expressions used to define the switching functions can contain comparisons and logical combinations. Comparisons are structured according to the following scheme: `<symbol> <comparative operator> <constant>`. This allows for complex conditions to be set for the activation of switch points.

6. **Switch-On and Switch-Off Delay**: Each switch point can have a switch-on and switch-off delay defined in seconds. This means that there can be a delay between the condition being met and the switch point being activated or deactivated. This feature helps to prevent false triggering due to transient conditions.

In summary, the switch points in the HYDACLAB switching outputs are defined using bit coding, logical expressions, and delays, and they are displayed as part of the analogue sequence. This comprehensive approach allows for precise control and monitoring of the switch points based on the device's status and predefined conditions.

## 4.3.2 Digital High Side Stages - - - - - -

Category: Comment ID: 592286 The digital high side stages (*IO_DO_00* ... *IO_DO_07*) provide the necessary diagnostic measures and are usable for safety-critical applications, when adhering to the subsequent requirements.

Category: Comment ID: 717651 Typically, the digital high side outputs of the HY-TTC 500 platform will be used for controlling valves. For a safe operation of these valves, the safety platform monitors the output level of the digital output signals, at runtime. In addition, the outputs are checked for short circuits to ground or power supply as well as for open circuits (e.g. cable break). <chunk_seperator> Category: Requirement Label: IO_Interrupt ID: 718456 Related To: Related To':
The application software **shall** not perform any I/O handling in the periodic interrupt handler function.

Category: Requirement Label: Task_Interrupt ID: 609581 Related To: Related To':
The application software **shall** not call the driver's task begin *IO_Driver_TaskBegin()* and task end functions *IO_Driver_TaskEnd()* from inside a periodic interrupt handler. Library functions being called from an interrupt handler might cause unexpected problems and the HY-TTC 500 platform may be unable to detect systematic software failures (e.g. infinite loops) in case an interrupt is used to service the window-watchdog.

## - - - - - 5.3 Runtime -

Category: Requirement Label: Main_Return ID: 717643 Related To: 712341 Related To':
The application's main function **shall** never return. <chunk_seperator> The computer screen appears to be in focus, but there are some blurry elements around it, such as a keyboard and mouse. The windows of the operating state and the operating hours serve as information only. No settings can be carried out from here. The HYDACLAB sensor counts the operating hours. The operating hours indicate the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset. The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature. The weighting is based on an Arrhenius calculation. HYDACLAB counts the amount of resets performed and is displayed as the number of reference cycles. The total number of operating hours describes the system's actual performed number of operating hours including the performed resets.

Question:  What must be used if both the "and" and "or" operators are used on the same level in logical expressions?
output: If both the "and" and "or" operators are used on the same level in logical expressions, parentheses must be used. This is necessary because the hierarchy of the "and" and "or" operators is not defined in mathematics. For example, instead of writing "T > 30 and P > 5.3 or C > 2.6," you should write "T > 30 and (P > 5.3 or C > 2.6)" or "(T > 30 and P > 5.3) or C > 2.6" to ensure the correct logical grouping and evaluation of the expressions.

The operating hours indicate the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset. The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature. The weighting is based on an Arrhenius calculation. HYDACLAB counts the amount of resets performed and is displayed as the number of reference cycles. The total number of operating hours describes the system's actual performed number of operating hours including the performed resets.

Question:  What does the HYDACLAB sensor count in relation to operating hours?
output: The HYDACLAB sensor counts the operating hours of the system. Specifically, it tracks the maximum expected operating hours since the last reset. Additionally, it counts the number of resets performed, which is displayed as the number of reference cycles. The total number of operating hours includes both the actual performed operating hours and the resets. The operating hours are influenced by the Arrhenius rate, which depends on temperature, and the weighting is based on an Arrhenius calculation.

Question:  What does the Arrhenius rate define in the context of operating hours?
output: The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature. This means that the operating hours are weighted based on an Arrhenius calculation, which takes into account the effect of temperature on the rate of chemical reactions. In this context, the Arrhenius rate is used to adjust the expected operating hours of the system, reflecting how temperature variations can influence the system's performance and longevity. The HYDACLAB sensor uses this calculation to provide a more accurate measure of the system's operating hours, considering the impact of temperature over time.

## 4.3.2 Digital High Side Stages - - - - - -

Category: Comment ID: 592286 The digital high side stages (*IO_DO_00* ... *IO_DO_07*) provide the necessary diagnostic measures and are usable for safety-critical applications, when adhering to the subsequent requirements.

Category: Comment ID: 717651 Typically, the digital high side outputs of the HY-TTC 500 platform will be used for controlling valves. For a safe operation of these valves, the safety platform monitors the output level of the digital output signals, at runtime. In addition, the outputs are checked for short circuits to ground or power supply as well as for open circuits (e.g. cable break). <chunk_seperator> Category: Requirement Label: IO_Interrupt ID: 718456 Related To: Related To':
The application software **shall** not perform any I/O handling in the periodic interrupt handler function.

Category: Requirement Label: Task_Interrupt ID: 609581 Related To: Related To':
The application software **shall** not call the driver's task begin *IO_Driver_TaskBegin()* and task end functions *IO_Driver_TaskEnd()* from inside a periodic interrupt handler. Library functions being called from an interrupt handler might cause unexpected problems and the HY-TTC 500 platform may be unable to detect systematic software failures (e.g. infinite loops) in case an interrupt is used to service the window-watchdog.

## - - - - - 5.3 Runtime -

Category: Requirement Label: Main_Return ID: 717643 Related To: 712341 Related To':
The application's main function **shall** never return. <chunk_seperator> The computer screen appears to be in focus, but there are some blurry elements around it, such as a keyboard and mouse. These peripherals are located on either side of the screen, with one closer to the top right corner and the other near the bottom left corner.)

The windows of the operating state and the operating hours serve as information only. No settings can be carried out from here. The HYDACLAB sensor counts the operating hours. The operating hours indicate the maximum expected operating hours of the system since its last reset. The Arrhenius rate defines the operating hours depending on temperature. The weighting is based on an Arrhenius calculation. HYDACLAB counts the amount of resets performed and is displayed as the number of reference cycles. The total number of operating hours describes the system's actual performed number of operating hours including the performed resets. 

## 5.4.5 Oil Condition Display 

![35_Image_0.Png](35_Image_0.Png) <chunk_seperator> <table_18>[{'The following elements are possible:  Symbol Comparative  operators': 'Logical operators'}, {'----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------': '----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------', '-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------': '---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------'}, {'C for conductivity': '= equal', 'and a connection
Question:  What is displayed as the number of reference cycles in the HYDACLAB system?
output: In the HYDACLAB system, the number of reference cycles is displayed as the count of resets performed. This means that each time the system is reset, it increments the reference cycle count, providing a record of how many times the system has been reset since its initial setup or last major maintenance. This information is crucial for tracking the maintenance history and understanding the system's usage patterns.

![35_Image_2.Png](35_Image_2.Png)

There are three different ways to perform a reset of the sensor. Reset to default settings means that all settings in the device are set back to its delivered status.

Reset reference cycle (see 7.1) means that all settings will be kept, except for the reference cycle data. Therefore, the reference cycle must be performed again, i.e. after an oil change. Reset log means that the fit table is kept but the data storage is cleared.

## Hydaclab **1400 Page 12**

5.5 Interface Description HSP (HYDAC Simple Protocol) The device has a serial interface. The user can communicate with the device via this interface. Data transmission at a baud rate of 9600 is possible via PIN 5 using the HSP protocol. The device supports the following functions: 
HSP Sensor Id Command 000 is supported. 

Device status Commands 010 and 011 are supported. Sensor Information Commands 020 and 021 are supported. <chunk_seperator> Device status Commands 010 and 011 are supported. Sensor Information Commands 020 and 021 are supported. 

Measured values Commands 030, 031 and 032 are supported. 

Read out Log Commands 060, 061 , 070, 071 and 072 are supported. 

Help Command 999 is supported. 

Detailed information can be found in the HSP protocol manual "HSP Specification". 

6 Start-up HYDACLAB starts its data storage as soon as it is connected to a voltage supply and the fluid temperature exceeds its activating temperature of 40°C (factory settings) for the first time. The output signals for temperature and saturation are available immediately after sensor start-up. The signal for relative change in the DC and relative change in the conductivity is displayed after the homogenisation phase is completed. The conductivity and the dielectric change is indicated as a percentage deviation from the reference value determined during the referencing phase. <chunk_seperator> ## 7.9.4.1 Example Of An Application

while (IO_RTC_GetTimeUS(timestamp) < 5000); **// wait until 5ms have passed** timestamp += 5000; **// increase time stamp by cycle time**

}

The whiteboard appears to be used for teaching or presenting information about various topics, such as scientific processes or engineering systems.)

During the referencing phase, the user must ensure that HYDACLAB is only supplied with voltage if the operating conditions of the machine/system are normal. 

(For example, the supply voltage of the sensor can be linked to the pump operation.) 
The sensor should be reset if, after the machine/system is part-filled or re-filled the analogue values for the relative change in dielectric constant and the electric conductivity do not fall within a window of ± 5 %. This can be caused by variations in oil characteristics in different oil batches. <chunk_seperator> 6.2 Reference Cycle During the referencing cycle HYDACLAB records the characteristics of the respective oil and adapts to the conditions of the relevant application. It is therefore essential that typical operating conditions, particularly all relevant operating temperature ranges, are run through during the reference phase. The end of the reference cycle is achieved when 50% of the working temperature is recorded and can be recognised from the LED as well as from the signal level of the status signal (see chapter 5.2). 

![37_image_0.png]( The image features a whiteboard with various diagrams and information displayed on it. There are multiple graphs and charts that showcase different stages of a process or a system. One of the main diagrams is a line graph illustrating the temperature of a table over time. <chunk_seperator> 6.1 Fit Table HYDACLAB continuously writes to a fit table in which the respectively defined conductivity and dielectric values for each temperature are stored. By means of this table, the measured values can be linked to a reference temperature. The fit table will be frozen on completion of the homogenisation phase. The frozen fit table provides a reference framework for the calculation of the conductivity and dielectric change. On delivery of the HYDACLAB the table is empty. The table is not written to until the activation temperature has been exceeded. <chunk_seperator> <table_125>[{'Pin No.': 'Function 1', 'Function 2': 'SW-define'}, {'-----------': '--------------------------------------', '---------------------------': '-------------'}, {'P107': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_08'}, {'P131': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_09'}, {'P108': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_10'}, {'P132': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_11'}, {'P109': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_12'}, {'P133': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_13'}, {'P110': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_14'}, {'P134': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 10 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': 'IO_ADC_15'}, {'P111': 'Analog 0. . . 5 V, 0. . . 32 V Input', 'Analog 0. . . 25 mA Input': <chunk_seperator> ## 5.4.5 Oil Condition Display 

![35_Image_0.Png](35_Image_0.Png)

With the oil condition screen you have the opportunity to define the warning and alarm thresholds of the sensor, each of which are linked to a LED. If the alarm threshold for conductivity change or DC change is set to +/- 0%, then they are not considered when displaying the oil condition.

## 5.4.6 Extended Settings "Lab Mode" 

![35_Image_1.Png](35_Image_1.Png)

"Lab Mode" switches off the referencing phase. The measured values DC and conductivity are recorded and output only as absolute values. There is no referencing phase and the "relative change in conductivity" and "relative change in DC" readings remain at 0%. 

5.4.7 Conductivity settings The default setting for conductivity is 0-100 nS / m. If the conductivity of the oil will never be more than 10 nS / m, then there is a possibility to set the conductivity scaling to 0-10 nS / m. 

## 5.4.8 Reset 

![35_Image_2.Png](35_Image_2.Png)
Question:  What can be defined using the oil condition screen in section 5.4.5?
output: Using the oil condition screen in section 5.4.5, you can define the warning and alarm thresholds of the sensor. Each threshold is linked to a corresponding LED indicator. This allows for monitoring and alerting based on changes in the oil's condition. Specifically, if the alarm threshold for conductivity change or DC change is set to +/- 0%, these parameters are not considered when displaying the oil condition. This customization helps in setting precise monitoring parameters tailored to specific operational needs and conditions.

Question:  What happens when "Lab Mode" is activated according to section 5.4.6?
output: When "Lab Mode" is activated, the referencing phase is switched off. This means that the measured values for DC (dielectric constant) and conductivity are recorded and output only as absolute values, without any referencing. Consequently, the readings for "relative change in conductivity" and "relative change in DC" will remain at 0%. This mode is useful for laboratory settings where absolute measurements are required without the need for referencing to a baseline or reference phase.
